Terri Hooley.Action: Stands up to bullies throwing projectiles at him, defends his father against slurs.
Creates and distributes homemade flyers promoting his events, showing initiative and hands-on involvement.
Wears a Kodak overall and works in a darkroom, indicating practical engagement with photography and media.
Displays a child-like, open expression that contrasts with some of his actions and words, suggesting an unusual or unconventional demeanor that may impact perceptions of competence.
Sings along to music despite alarm, showing carefree friendliness.
Engages warmly and playfully with Kodak women, calling one 'The future Mrs Hooley' and invites them sincerely.
Responds to difficult situation (bomb disposal) calmly and respectfully by removing record and leaving.
Dismisses Eric’s defeatism in a friendly manner, trying to cheer him up.
Spreads arms wide after women leave, saying 'I have a life wish.'
Sticks flyers to Marty and Ned’s backs after being rebuffed.
Encourages Marty to go out dancing and reconnect with joy.
Laughs together with Ruth at the OLD BOY sneezing, showing camaraderie.
Openly admits to having lost many friends due to political and social conflicts but still maintains connections on a personal level.
Shows tolerance by acknowledging he doesn't consider himself Catholic or Protestant despite having those friends.
Remarks that he is now more choosy about friends, suggesting a guardedness.
Engages kindly with Ruth by inviting her to write on a notepad and sharing a moment.
Efficiently organizing moving boxes and directing where to put records and clothes.
Flicks ash into an ashtray while ranting, showing casual inattentiveness to surroundings.
Makes witty comments and jokes to relieve tension while moving.
Engages in small talk and light social interaction rather than focusing on major tasks.
Comforts Eric after he reveals he was attacked and shows concern by wincing at the shears incident.
Uses sarcastic language 'Fuck me.' and 'For what, dealing a bit of blow?' which may show a defensive or tough exterior but also familiarity and sincerity in tone.
Expresses affection sincerely to Ruth, saying 'You are everything to me.'
Comforts Ruth by gently touching her hair while reaffirming his feelings.
Despite fear and physical attack by thugs, tries to resist and escape without hurting others deliberately.
Attempts to get funding by presenting a cause (bringing reggae to Belfast) confidently and persistently.
Leaves the meeting disappointed but not defeated, showing resilience despite apparent failure.
Hesitates when asked about collateral, indicating awareness of limitations but also possible insecurity or lack of resources.
Manages to secure forty pounds to fund his venture, creatively negotiating despite limited means.
Suggests a meeting between rival paramilitary groups and uses records as a peace offering, managing to get everyone to sit down and share.
Approaches a stall and confidently offers a low price for a large bunch of records, demonstrating savvy negotiation.
Uses informal, irreverent language with potentially hostile groups but maintains control of the situation.
Draws on a cigarette and pauses before making calls, showing a calm and controlled demeanor.
Distributes records fairly between Republican and Loyalist paramilitaries to ensure everyone is happy.
Requests that no one come around asking for donations for prisoners or widows, and explicitly asks no one try to kill him.
Tries to maintain peace by using music and humor amidst tense paramilitary presence.
Jokes lightly by asking for 'one for the road' after serious demands, lightening the mood.
Skillfully negotiates sharing albums between paramilitary groups and sets clear boundaries to avoid conflict, showing confidence and situational awareness.
Confidently defuses a potentially tense situation by requesting no violence and no solicitation of donations, revealing social intelligence and risk management.
Displays good humor and self-awareness when responding to Andy's compliment, indicating personal confidence.
Underestimates the difficulty of influencing younger, more volatile skinheads despite a confident claim about his record collection, indicating possible overconfidence or naivety.
Hugs Pugwash warmly upon his arrival in the street.
Slips brandy from his flask into elderflower champagne to celebrate with friends.
Encourages customers by shouting approval of their music choice.
Under his breath, expresses resigned apprehension when two RUC officers enter his shop.
Opens the shop and creates an inviting atmosphere in a bleak environment, managing practical tasks like opening a cash register, organizing coins, and setting music on the turntable.
Responds calmly and informally to the RUC men entering the shop, showing awareness but no panic.
Tops up his drink from a hidden flask, suggesting reliance on alcohol during work hours.
Encourages a customer to buy a record with enthusiasm but misreads the customer's reaction, resulting in the customer leaving without purchasing.
Stands up defiantly and provocatively to RUC man, joining in singing with the punks against the police despite danger.
Hugs punks in the chaotic aftermath, tolerating accidental head-butting without visible anger.
Cries overwhelmed by the working-class youth and music scene around him, showing emotional vulnerability.
Takes the initiative to sign and put out a record for an unknown band despite uncertainty and skepticism from others.
Acknowledges lack of knowledge on how to make the record but proceeds confidently anyway.
Is physically disheveled and emotionally overwhelmed but still focused on his goal.
Pushes aside people awkwardly and hugs band members unaware of their discomfort.
Wakes Ruth in the middle of the night to share the excitement about the kids playing music, insisting she must hear them.
Jokes with Outcasts' singer Greg when he asks for a recording, saying he’s not that drunk.
Insists on recording a band despite concerns about being too intoxicated, showing confidence in his judgment.
Enthusiastically shares his excitement about the music with Ruth at four in the morning, demonstrating passion but perhaps lack of consideration for timing or others' rest.
Approaches mixing desk confidently by asking directly which man is Davy, showing straightforward and clear communication.
Sidles up and drapes an arm over Davy Smyth’s shoulder, trying to connect personally.
Expresses disappointment and challenges the dull bookings (flute bands and crisps jingles) with humor and sincerity.
Lights and smokes a spliff casually in front of others, showing relaxed openness.
Tries to negotiate for a better rehearsal time, emphasizing camaraderie as 'music people'.
Appears impatient and slightly frustrated at scheduling, but remains friendly.
Uses light sarcasm (‘That’s all I need, another two Davys in my life.’) which could be interpreted as mildly dismissive but playful.
Trusts the bank manager with his plan for printing 3,000 records despite initial skepticism.
Shares in the collective effort to fold printing sheets quickly with colleagues Ruth, Marilyn, and Dave.
Slips twenty quid to Davy Smyth discreetly to support the pressing process.
Expresses defiant disdain toward major record labels (EMI, Polydor) with the phrase 'Up your hole, EMI.'
Supports punk kids by advocating for them to have their own space and shows optimism about the venue's capacity and usage.
Engages politely and warmly with Ruth and Mavis at dinner, uses 'please' after being prompted, demonstrating courtesy.
Offers Pugwash free accommodation rather than charging rent despite financial constraints.
Jokes warmly with band members, calls them 'your new label-mates' to Brian, showing inclusiveness.
Refuses to wait passively for others to change, showing proactive support for his bands.
Plays along with affectionate teasing and laughter with younger band members.
Uses mild profanity ('Fucker's lucky I don’t charge him rent') which could be abrasive but contextually shows casual, friendly protectiveness.
Interrupts a conversation about political losses with a sarcastic question about alternatives (not directly toward warmth).
Uses humor to respond to uncertainty about their route ('We’re on the road to Damascus') despite not actually knowing the location.
Successfully encourages local rural kids to join the punk band's performance, increasing participation despite initial hostility.
Manages to negotiate or interact with the Rural Hall Manager about the disorder caused, calmly reaching for his wallet.
Tries to explain their situation calmly to the soldiers, attempts to defuse tension.
Quietly waits and endures the soldiers' aggression without retaliation.
Keeps calm and talks to soldiers when stopped, tries to explain their situation clearly.
Is disorganized with cassette tapes, unable to remember their origins.
Responds to Soldiers' questions without judgment or sectarian bias, saying 'It never occurred to me to ask' about religious affiliations.
Seemingly tolerant and unaffected by sectarian divisions when interacting with Soldiers.
Throws himself back on the bed and squeezes his eyes shut after waking, showing signs of internal distress but no outward hostility or bitterness.
Allows various outcasts and tearjerkers to sleep on the floor of his home, indicating hospitality and acceptance.
Admits he never considered the religious affiliations of the group members when asked by Soldier 1.
Engages in conversation with armed soldiers, maintaining composure and avoiding conflict.
Appears tired and overwhelmed, throwing himself back on the bed and shutting his eyes in frustration.
Bars Mutt and Hatchet from entering after they give him lip, stands firm despite threats.
Engages in a witty verbal exchange with Mutt, showing confidence and a lighthearted toughness.
Walks through Good Vibes receiving cheers from customers, indicating positive relationships and trust.
Allows Ruth to warmly wrap arms around him, indicating closeness and friendliness.
Bars Mutt and Hatchet from the venue despite their threats, maintaining control calmly and confidently.
Engages in a verbal power struggle and shows quick wit by matching threats with humor and authority.
Stands his ground in a potentially dangerous situation without backing down.
Allows Elvis to be punched by Mutt and Hatchet without intervening physically, which could suggest limitations in handling physical threats.
Responds brusquely to a negative letter, shows frustration but keeps trying.
Tells the Undertones he is busy and dismisses their effort initially.
Admits the tape 'wasn't bad' and avoids outright rejection despite pressure.
Shows concern for the band's situation when Feargal mentions breaking up; physically pained by the news.
Attempts to consider Feargal's worries by leaving to buy cigarettes and promises to return with an answer.
Laughs quietly and smiles awkwardly when tapped on the wrist by Feargal, indicating a friendly, informal rapport.
Dismisses the seriousness of the record label's situation initially calling it 'not really a proper label', potentially downplaying others' concerns.
Frustratedly asking customers for cigarettes and calling them punks when they don't have any.
Asks customers repeatedly for cigarettes but finds none available; shows frustration but advances the interaction confidently.
Delegates responsibility to Pugwash to 'steer the ship' while he steps away, showing some trust and leadership.
Walks purposefully with Feargal and engages in serious conversation about the record label's future, indicating some situational awareness and engagement.
Admits Good Vibrations isn’t really a proper label and responds evasively when pressed about progressing the band’s record.
Appears physically pained and reluctant when confronted with the band’s breakup, suggesting emotional vulnerability that may affect decisiveness.
Uses a vague promise to buy cigarettes before giving an answer to Feargal, possibly delaying confrontation or commitment.
Maintains composure and charm with a smile while subtly hiding emotions (lighting a cigarette, smiling discreetly), showing emotional control.
Unloads beer, crisps, and rolls for the band in the studio.
Spreads hands on the glass watching the band intently, showing deep concern and involvement.
Says 'Well I won’t be posting this one to London' after hearing a track he does not like.
Organizes and leads the mass folding of ‘Teenage Kicks’ EP sleeves, explaining the process clearly and repeating it to ensure understanding.
Scrambles to his feet pleasingly when George arrives, showing alertness and respect.
Responds to George's ironic challenge by turning up the volume on the record, showing confidence and defiance.
Trying to squeeze an excessive number of records into a plastic bag, forcing things beyond reasonable limits.
Shows concern and self-awareness about how others might perceive him, not wanting to give anyone an excuse.
Refuses drugs to avoid messing up his performance, showing self-awareness and focus.
Confidently approaches a record executive and interacts with various influential people, indicating resourcefulness and social skill.
Initially appears confused or surprised by the executive's demand for 'guns, bombs, tanks' metaphor, suggesting a possible gap in understanding the punk scene's expected attitude.
Stands up passionately for the music and his bands despite harsh criticism and rejection from record executives.
Responds aggressively by throwing discs at an executive after being told the music is 'shit'.
Shows intense emotional investment and a protective attitude toward his bands, indicating sincerity and loyalty.
Storms out quickly after initial criticism, showing impulsiveness and difficulty handling rejection calmly.
Stands up to multiple record executives despite harsh criticism, passionately defends his music choices.
Loses temper by throwing discs and is forcibly removed by security, appearing emotionally overwhelmed.
Persistently tries to hand out records despite rejection and hostility.
Attempts to deliver vinyl to the BBC personally despite clear security barriers.
Admits to messing up and tries emotional appeal by dropping to his knees.
Fails to understand or recognize the person who helps him (Des).
Expresses regret for not delivering a record in person, believing it was worth being arrested.
Brightens upon seeing Des, showing friendly recognition.
Switches off radio abruptly after emotional reaction, then leaves the room.
Celebrates with Ruth enthusiastically when 'Teenage Kicks' is replayed on air.
Jokes about seating in the van to lighten the mood.
Reassures Paul that he doesn't need to sell Seymour Stein to him, showing trust and friendliness.
Allows Mickey Bradley to have the phone conversation with Seymour Stein, showing trust in others.
Silently leaves the room after the difficult phone call, avoiding confrontation.
Tells others they should be advising him rather than the reverse, showing confidence in his role.
Calms the growling dog by commanding 'Down boy', showing calm control in tense situations.
Shows resilience and self-confidence by refusing to sell his record for a large sum, despite prior rejection, indicating strong self-belief and principled stance.
Does not respond immediately to the dog’s growling but simply says 'Down boy' without escalating conflict.
Faces technical issues during journey (rain, broken wiper, tape deck cutting out) but does not show visible frustration or loss of composure.
Offers to buy the van for a fair price with a humorous touch involving a signed photo, creating a friendly atmosphere.
Expresses confidence and support to Getty by encouraging his success with Rudi and the Undertones.
Offers Getty a bottle of brandy and shares a moment of reflection looking out the window, showing camaraderie and genuine concern.
Negotiates and decisively agrees on purchasing a van for £500, showing confidence in his offer despite skepticism from others.
Uses humor and lightheartedness ('a signed photo of the Shangri-las') during negotiations to ease tension and build rapport.
Encourages Getty with a confident statement about his and Rudi's future success, demonstrating motivational leadership.
Momentary expression of doubt after the deal but quickly regains composure, showing emotional regulation.
Offers to get Brian’s band on TV if he writes new songs.
Looks abashed but cooperates when approached by German journalist for interview.
Swallows pint quickly but still abandons half before leaving, indicating some discomfort or avoidance.
Offers to help local musician Brian by encouraging him to write new songs so he can get exposure on TV.
Responds abashedly but sits for an interview when approached by a German journalist and photographer.
Brings lunch to Ruth and shares sausage rolls with her.
Apologizes for his behavior the previous night.
Shows genuine excitement about becoming a father.
Sits quietly with Ruth after learning about her pregnancy, not immediately responding verbally.
Attempts to comfort Ruth with light conversation but misses the emotional depth she seeks.
Sits quietly and observes a silent protest with empathy, paying attention to political prisoners' messages.
Covers anti-H Block posters with his own Harp posters, promoting an alternative message.
Decides to work twice as hard despite uncertainty.
Struggles to light a cigarette due to shaking hands, indicating nervousness or stress.
Observes carefully the changing political signs and silent protest, showing awareness and attentiveness.
Covers political posters with Harp posters, demonstrating initiative and strategic thinking.
Pats Davy Smyth's shoulder after he finishes writing on the tape box.
Answers phone with friendly tone, refers to himself with humor 'That’s nice of you to say so.'
Encourages putting on a really great band on a show he’s been watching.
Takes the 'Pressure's On - Master' tape from Davy Smyth and places it in his record bag, showing involvement in the production and distribution process.
Engages confidently on the phone, presenting himself as 'That Terri Hooley' and negotiating to put on a great band, demonstrating self-assurance and promotional skill.
Rips the magazine cover off in frustration or casualness, causing other items to fall to the floor, indicating a possible lack of carefulness or control.
Watches sleeves rolling off the press, indicating attention to product completion and quality control.
Lists numerous pressures including the shop, band members, bank, and a wife about to have a baby, showing he is overwhelmed but still engaged.
Does not chase after band members who walk out despite the opportunity being important, choosing instead to go to the Siouxsie gig.
Tries to juggle multiple serious responsibilities at once (shop, bar, band, bank issues, pregnant wife).
Fails to get the record out on time, causing a lost opportunity for the band.
Decides not to chase the band after they quit, shows prioritization by heading to the Siouxsie gig.
Defends punk kids as a solution to Belfast's problems, showing appreciation and support for marginalized youth.
Receives claps on the back and shares stories with others at the after-show party, including making Siouxsie laugh.
Is half-cut (drunk) before the show, which could indicate a lack of self-control but does not directly reflect warmth.
Sits by Ruth's hospital bed through the night, sharing a quiet moment with her and the baby.
Replies to Ruth that he has been there for ten minutes but doesn't wake her up, respecting her rest.
Describes the baby as gorgeous and admits his hands are shaking too much to hold her, showing nervousness and care.
Brings his friends (Greg, Fangs, Lanky Punk) into the hospital ward despite the inappropriate setting, causing trouble.
Defends his friends by saying they are 'practically family' when Ruth criticizes him.
Mumbles that he has to go and leaves when Ruth signals he should, avoiding further conflict.
Admits his hands are shaking and he is too nervous to hold the baby, showing self-awareness and honesty but lack of confidence in the moment.
Brings rowdy friends into the hospital ward despite the environment being inappropriate, resulting in conflict with the nurse.
Responds with some calm to Ruth’s declaration that she wants to leave, tries to reassure her.
Approaches a young male journalist warmly, putting hands on his shoulders, engaging sincerely in conversation even when drunk.
Describes trying to help by being Belfast correspondent for Oz magazine, showing effort to communicate and connect.
Attempts to become a correspondent for Oz magazine by proposing a Belfast beat but is rejected.
Engages confidently and famously with John Lennon, showing enthusiasm and zeal in explaining the Belfast situation.
Looks up in horror at a car boot filled with guns and grenades, expresses shock.
Slams down a glass on the counter in a nearly empty bar, talks to himself indicating frustration and isolation.
Throws a punch at John Lennon.
Clicks fingers at man playing fruit machine to put money in phone, man ignores him.
Sits on settee, curls up trying to sleep, showing vulnerability and perhaps exhaustion.
Throws a fistful of bills at the police land rover to show he isn't dealing drugs, showing a candid and bold attitude.
Admits to always drinking too much and casually normalizes heavy drinking among everyone they know, showing a lack of self-restraint and possible disregard for others' concern.
Unconvincingly claims a tape box is a back-up when confronted, suggesting avoidance or disorganization.
Confronts young punks suspected of thieving but does not accuse them outright and refrains from immediate judgment or violence.
Behaves sarcastically and aggressively during an argument with Dave, mocking and insulting him.
After argument with Dave, shows some care by noticing Dave didn’t drink his brandy and mentions it.
Pays more attention to his pint than to the band and the aggressive atmosphere appearing on the dance floor.
Admits impulsively taking actions without thinking but defends himself by citing past successes like Big Time, the tour, and Teenage Kicks.
Leaves a negative impression on Ruth who urges him to 'open your eye', suggesting a failure to notice or acknowledge important realities.
Contemplates his reflection and appears as 'an absolute mess', indicating self-awareness of personal or professional shortcomings.
Interacts dismissively and confidently with Mutt and Hatchet who come with a demo tape, pushing them away but maintaining control of the situation.
Refuses to support racist and offensive band names, saying 'I'd sooner sell bog rolls than Nazi shite like that.'
Endures a violent beating submissively and does not retaliate or respond with anger afterwards.
Refuses to sell offensive, racist material despite pressure.
Shows fear and ultimately is physically beaten without fighting back.
Insists on hosting the concert at Ulster Hall despite skepticism, showing faith in his vision and determination.
Insists on featuring only Good Vibrations bands rather than more famous or commercial acts, showing loyalty and support for his community.
Participates actively in putting up posters with friends and associates, demonstrating friendliness and commitment to the cause.
Remonstrates with the front of house manager to open the doors and lets a dozen punks in despite obstacles.
Tells the crowd outside not to worry, that they'll all get in.
Addresses the crowd humbly, rejects hierarchical labels by saying 'No leaders! No godfathers!'
Thanks the audience sincerely and speaks about community and belonging, calling Good Vibrations 'a way of life'
Walks on stage to a roaring crowd, accepts recognition but rejects the notion of leadership with humility and promotes a collective spirit.
Struggles to be heard over the noise initially, indicating some difficulty in commanding immediate attention.
Runs offstage triumphant, reveling in the success of the event despite financial loss.
Tries to de-escalate physical aggression from Dave by trying to prise open his fingers.
Admits to Ruth that he is sorry about the guest lists, appearing shamefaced.
Runs on stage to join bands and celebrate with everyone, showing camaraderie and community spirit.
Oblivious to financial concerns and practicalities, focusing only on emotional and symbolic victories.
Shares a vulnerable and inclusive performance with others, highlighting acceptance despite judgment.
Expresses care and empathy through song by promising to pray and do good for others.
Leads a musical performance confidently, engages with bandmates and audience, shows emotional connection through eye contact and interaction.
Carries on singing seamlessly despite hallucination or substitution of bandmate with Hank Williams, showing adaptability and focus.
Confidently stands up and corrects a prejudice by telling the boys his father is a socialist, showing awareness and willingness to assert his viewpoint.
Exposes himself to physical danger by popping up at the wrong moment to confront the boys, resulting in being hit by an arrow.
Sings along to music while preparing flyers for a gig, shows child-like openness and enthusiasm.
Exclaims ‘What a fucking nightmare’ upon seeing news of explosions, showing candid emotional reaction.
Notices the bomb disposal man and carefully takes the record off before leaving, showing situational awareness and caution.
Returns quickly to grab a handful of flyers after leaving, demonstrating decisiveness and commitment to his cause.
Ignores an alarm going off and starts singing again, indicating some lack of situational attentiveness.
Engages people (women in Kodak overalls), handing out flyers and attempting to promote his event, showing initiative and social skill.
Is described as 'a bit skint', implying financial struggles that might affect his ability to act effectively but does not impact competence directly.
Confronts potential danger with humor and confidence (arms spread, 'I have a life wish').
Uses subtle tricks like sticking flyers to the backs of people leaving him off (Marty and Ned).
Interacts with security by playfully using a glass eye to trigger a buzzer, showing resourcefulness and familiarity with the environment.
Continues singing along with a record, showing genuine enjoyment and passion for music.
Defends the value of playing music despite the venue being empty and the manager wanting to stop the gig.
Interacts warmly and kindly with Ruth, engaging her in conversation and sharing a laugh at the old man's sneeze.
Demonstrates awareness of complex social dynamics and adapts friendships accordingly.
Shows self-awareness and thoughtfully selects friends rather than clinging to past alliances.
Engages warmly and humorously in conversation despite complicated social histories.
Does not clearly demonstrate any inability or failure in this excerpt.
Playfully teases Ruth by asking if she is Martian; warmly welcomes her as the first name on his new guest list.
Offers to go to his parents’ house but respects Ruth’s preference; reciprocates friendliness by walking with her.
Engages in light-hearted and intimate behavior with Ruth, such as climbing into the bin together, demonstrating playful trust and connection.
Confidently initiates contact and builds social connections, creates a new guest list, and uses playful banter to engage Ruth.
Engages in somewhat impulsive behavior such as climbing into and hiding in a bin, which may come across as unorthodox and risky.
Shares a light-hearted joke about Eric's cowboy hat, demonstrating playful friendliness.
Carefully places his ashtray on the floor and reminds Dave to mind his feet, showing consideration for others.
Engages in moving into a new home with Ruth and friends, suggesting community and collaboration.
Acknowledges the violent nature of a past acquaintance honestly, showing realism without bitterness.
Rejects the idea of escaping danger, showing courage and determination.
Distractedly knocks over bag of records but helps to pick them up, showing some care and responsibility.
Expresses a clear vision to open a record shop despite difficulties, indicating optimistic and sincere intentions.
Says no to leaving when advised to do so, showing resolve not to give in to fear or expectations.
Attempts to open a record shop by confidently approaching a bank manager despite lack of collateral.
Knocks over a bag of records in a moment of agitation, showing some lack of composure.
Hugs Ruth and Dave, sharing a friendly gesture and expressing 'One love'.
After their visit with the Peace People, dismisses them with 'Fucking hippies.'
Listens silently and broods when Ruth reveals her new job as a truant officer, showing concern.
Hesitates when the bank manager asks for collateral, implying discomfort or lack of resources.
Calmly mediates between hostile paramilitary groups by encouraging them to share music records and sit down together.
Offers a modest amount of money for a lot of low-value records.
Uses mild insults to refer to paramilitary groups but follows with an attempt to unify them.
Interacts with Fangs, a punk kid, initially with skepticism but then shows willingness to help by ordering records he doesn't have.
Engages in light teasing and banter with Pugwash, showing friendly familiarity.
Shakes head dismissively at Fangs' crude language initially, showing some judgment or impatience.
Recognizes potential in FANGS' attitude, takes initiative to order punk records he doesn't have, and facilitates local punk gigs by posting flyers in his shop.
Initially mistakes FANGS’ request and seems unaware of the punk scene details (e.g., confusion about John Peel playing Pink Floyd), showing some lack of knowledge.
Pushes through crowd to buttonhole RUC man and writes down the name of a pink-haired punk girl during a police raid
Shows frustration with Dave's comment about the Pound morgue by saying 'Fuck sake, Dave.'
Navigates a tense environment confidently, engages directly with an RUC man to report an incident despite the risk, shows situational awareness and assertiveness.
Brings Dave to a risky location with potential danger and unrest, possibly showing poor judgment or disregard for others’ concerns.
Stands his ground facing armed police, boldly refuses to back down when ordered.
Joins in singing provocatively against the police, contributing to turning the situation in the crowd's favor.
Engages physically and emotionally in chaotic crowd moments, showing resilience despite possible injury.
Emotional breakdown (crying) amidst the intensity of the scene.
Stands up for the band, offers to put out their record despite obstacles, shows enthusiasm and support.
Hugs the band members warmly, despite their discomfort.
Leans at the bar with his head in his hands, shares a candid view of the night, showing vulnerability.
Assesses the venue's capacity and potential attendance confidently, estimating crowd sizes and frequency of events.
Leans toward the stage to inspect it closely, showing attention to detail and engagement.
Attempts casual conversation and social interaction during home dinner, demonstrating ease but minimal leadership.
Promises bands to get them heard, sends records to multiple companies.
Refuses to become a crook despite industry pressure.
Plans to take a few groups on the road to showcase them despite dangers.
Dismisses George's cynical view with a straightforward rebuttal 'Catch yourself on, dad.'
Shows frustration and dismisses returned record with crude response; appears scattered and distracted by petty concerns like missing cigarettes during band meeting.
Admits he hasn’t listened properly to an important tape but acknowledges potential in the band ('wasn't bad'), showing some recognition of talent.
Expresses regret for not personally delivering the record despite the risk, showing awareness of responsibility and stakes involved.
Switches off the radio and walks out after feeling guilty, demonstrating emotional sensitivity but possibly momentary loss of composure.
Misses the moment 'Teenage Kicks' ends on the radio, indicating a lapse in attention at a crucial time.
Responds dismissively to a potential business call from Sire Records, refusing to engage over the phone and insisting the caller come in person.
Remains calm and composed while standing outside under an army helicopter’s spotlight, showing a sense of calm under pressure.
Jokes with Paul about seating arrangements in the van, showing relaxed confidence and control of social dynamics.
Demonstrates deep knowledge and respect for industry figures by supporting Seymour Stein and referencing the Shangri-las call, indicating insight and confidence.
Allows Mickey to take the phone call and then quietly leaves the room, suggesting trust in others' abilities but possibly avoiding direct confrontation or negotiation.
Stops a pink-haired punk girl’s exaggerated search for money and wearily waves her in.
Poses for photos with cartoon punks, capering around and hollering along with the music.
Walks past a tired Ruth and sets a beer can on the laundry basket lid without interacting.
Responds vaguely and dismissively to band members who ask about delays in releasing the record, blaming others ('those useless bastards').
Allows a punk girl to enter the bar despite her exaggerated pantomime search for money, showing relaxed but effective social control.
Engages playfully and energetically with punk musicians and friends, demonstrating enthusiasm and social ease.
Successfully gets the band Rudi on TV to promote their record, indicating some skill in promotion and networking.
Fails to ensure the band’s record is released on time despite promising to do so; responds vaguely and dismissively when questioned about the problem.
Speaks confidently about punk culture's positive impact on Belfast, showing insight and leadership.
Is seen half-cut and drinking during events, which may indicate impaired professionalism or focus.
Sits quietly by Ruth's bedside in the hospital, wearing the same clothes from the night before, indicating a willingness to be present but lacking active caregiving or initiative.
Smiles and sways alone at Ulster Hall, showing a relaxed and confident demeanor in a social setting.
Threw out the address needed to send a reminder for an unpaid order.
Unable to locate important documents related to payment despite ongoing search.
Admits to drinking excessively despite being confronted about it.
Sees Lanky Punk with a gun, calmly covers the weapon, expresses concern and offers to pay for taxis to keep him safe.
Silent confrontation when accused of thieving, neither escalating nor backing down.
Runs after Ruth and gets into a cramped lift with her despite tension, showing a willingness to connect.
Calmly intervenes to stop Fangs from carrying a gun and offers to pay for taxis to prevent risky behavior.
Confronts bank manager about serious financial troubles but appears overwhelmed and unable to immediately resolve them.
Quickly pursues Ruth in the corridor and acts decisively to engage with her.
Admits to acting impulsively without thinking but acknowledges it is part of who he is and notes his relative success.
Tells Mutt and Hatchet to 'fuck off' and sarcastically mocks them.
Allows Mavis to tend to his injuries patiently, engages in light teasing with her, showing a relaxed and familiar interaction.
Takes initiative to serve George a drink to prevent Mavis from getting upset about it cooling down.
Forgets about the mug in his hand and seems a bit distracted or absent-minded during the interaction with George.
Engages in conversation about family, showing respectful and considerate attitude towards his mother’s and George’s views.
Responds humorously to Mavis about the police and door incident, indicating quick wit and resilient attitude after being battered.
Almost forgets holding a mug while talking with George, showing absentmindedness or distraction in the moment.
Engages attentively in conversation and shows concern by offering the mug before his mother reacts negatively.
Acknowledges he has taken his eye off the ball and calls for focus to organize a fundraiser gig.
Uses humor to diffuse tension among band members before steering conversation towards practical matters.
Physical gestures of picking things up off the floor and counter mirroring verbal attempts at setting things straight.
Does not yet have a clear plan for the gig venue, showing some uncertainty when challenged by Dave.
Insists on booking the Ulster Hall (a large venue) for a Good Vibrations gig despite others doubting it, demonstrating confidence and knowledge of the venue's capacity and past experience.
Rejects the suggestion to book famous headline acts like the Clash or Siouxsie, insisting the gig will feature Good Vibrations bands only, showing clear commitment and vision.
Pushes forward with large scale promotion by personally postering around Belfast to advertise the gig.
Runs offstage triumphant, expressing pride in the event despite financial loss.
Carries in his head the longest guest list in the hall’s history, showing strong memory and organizational skill.
Is confronted for losing money on a packed event aimed to raise funds, showing lack of financial control or planning.
Prioritizes symbolic victory of 'taking back Belfast' over financial success, reflecting a value-driven but perhaps impractical approach.
Appears shamefaced when questioned about guest lists and owing money to Ruth, indicating an awareness of mistakes but lack of accountability.
Runs on stage displaying confidence and leadership, encouraging bands and audience to celebrate collectively.
